explanation: The principle of least action states that the path taken by a physical system between two configurations is the one that makes the action stationary. The action is defined as the time integral of the Lagrangian function. This principle provides a unified foundation for classical mechanics and leads directly to the Euler-Lagrange equations of motion.

definitions.definition: Action functional, the time integral of the Lagrangian over a given time interval.
Lagrangian function, typically the difference between kinetic and potential energy.
Generalized coordinates describing the configuration of the system.
Generalized velocities, time derivatives of generalized coordinates.
Initial and final times defining the time interval for the action integral.
First variation of the action under small changes in the path.

assumptions.text: The system can be described by a finite number of generalized coordinates `q_i(t)` and their time derivatives `dot q_i(t)`.
The Lagrangian `L(q_i, dot q_i, t)` is a well-defined function of the generalized coordinates, velocities, and possibly time.
The Lagrangian is at least twice continuously differentiable with respect to all its arguments.
The path `q_i(t)` is smooth and differentiable on the interval `[t_1, t_2]`.
The endpoints of the path are fixed: `delta q_i(t_1) = delta q_i(t_2) = 0`.
The variations `delta q_i(t)` are small and arbitrary within the interior of the time interval.

derivation.description: Define the action functional as the time integral of the Lagrangian along a path `q_i(t)` with `i = 1,...,n`.
derivation.equation: S[q] = int_(t_1)^(t_2) L(q_i(t), dot(q_i)(t), t) dt

derivation.description: Embed the given path into a one-parameter family (the variation direction) and fix endpoints: `q_i^(epsilon)(t) = q_i(t) + epsilon eta_i(t)`, with `eta_i(t_1)=eta_i(t_2)=0`. Define `S(epsilon) = int L(q_i^(epsilon), dot(q_i)^(epsilon), t) dt`.
derivation.equation: q_i^(epsilon)(t) = q_i(t) + epsilon eta_i(t), eta_i(t_1)=eta_i(t_2)=0; S(epsilon) = int_(t_1)^(t_2) L(q_i^(epsilon)(t), dot(q_i)^(epsilon)(t), t) dt

derivation.description: Define the first variation as the derivative of `S(epsilon)` at `epsilon=0` and move the derivative inside the integral (assuming smoothness).
derivation.equation: delta S := d/(d epsilon) S(epsilon)|_(epsilon=0) = int_(t_1)^(t_2) d/(d epsilon) L(q_i^(epsilon), dot(q_i)^(epsilon), t)|_(epsilon=0) dt

derivation.description: Apply the chain rule with respect to `epsilon` at fixed `t`. Since `q_i^(epsilon)(t)` depends on `epsilon` only via the variation, we have `(partial q_i^(epsilon))/(partial epsilon) = eta_i` and `(partial dot(q_i)^(epsilon))/(partial epsilon) = dot(eta_i)`.
derivation.equation: d/(d epsilon) L(q_i^(epsilon), dot(q_i)^(epsilon), t) = sum_(i=1)^n ( (del L)/(del q_i) eta_i + (del L)/(del dot(q_i)) dot(eta_i) )

derivation.description: Evaluate at `epsilon=0` and substitute into `delta S`.
derivation.equation: delta S = int_(t_1)^(t_2) sum_(i=1)^n ( (del L)/(del q_i) eta_i + (del L)/(del dot(q_i)) dot(eta_i) ) dt

derivation.description: Integrate the term with `dot(eta_i)` by parts, using `dot(eta_i) = d eta_i/dt`.
derivation.equation: int_(t_1)^(t_2) (del L)/(del dot(q_i)) dot(eta_i) dt = [(del L)/(del dot(q_i)) eta_i]_(t_1)^(t_2) - int_(t_1)^(t_2) d/dt((del L)/(del dot(q_i))) eta_i dt

derivation.description: Use the endpoint conditions `eta_i(t_1)=eta_i(t_2)=0` to eliminate the boundary term.
Collect terms to express the first variation solely in terms of `eta_i(t)`.
derivation.equation: delta S = int_(t_1)^(t_2) sum_(i=1)^n ( (del L)/(del q_i) - d/dt((del L)/(del dot(q_i))) ) eta_i dt

derivation.description: By the fundamental lemma of the calculus of variations, `delta S = 0` for all independent `eta_i` with `eta_i(t_1)=eta_i(t_2)=0` implies the coefficients vanish.
derivation.equation: d/(dt)((del L)/(del dot(q_i))) - (del L)/(del q_i) = 0, i=1,...,n
